abstract: Former NFL quarterback Ken Stabler, who died in 2015 at age 69, and who is finalist for Pro Football Hall of Fame's 2016 class, had high Stage 3 chronic traumatic encephalopathy, degenerative brain disease believed to be caused by repeated blows to head; Stabler is one of highest-profile football players to have had CTE, with list including at least seven Hall of Fame members; family of Super Bowl quarterback Earl Morrall has now reported that he was found to have Stage 4 CTE after his death in 2014 at age 79.

headline.print_headline: A Magnetic N.F.L. Star, Sapped of Spirit by a Disease of the Brain
headline.main: Ken Stabler, a Magnetic N.F.L. Star, Was Sapped of Spirit by C.T.E.

snippet: Stabler, a former Raiders quarterback known for his charisma, had high Stage 3 chronic traumatic encephalopathy when he died at 69 in July, researchers said.
lead_paragraph: Stabler, a former Raiders quarterback known for his charisma, had high Stage 3 chronic traumatic encephalopathy when he died at 69 in July, researchers said.
